## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Interplanetary Shock
##
## Message Issue Date: 2022-07-31T13:41:24Z
## Message ID: 20220731-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significant interplanetary shock detected by DSCOVR at L1 at 2022-07-31T08:20Z. Magnetospheric compression and geomagnetic storm may be expected. 

Activity ID: 2022-07-31T08:20:00-IPS-001.

## Notes: 

The cause of this event is under analysis.

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2022-07-30T19:16:34Z
## Message ID: 20220730-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu starting at 2022-07-25T14:05Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels may be caused by CME with ID 2022-07-21T01:36:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20220721-AL-003, 20220722-AL-001) and  CME with ID 2022-07-21T01:48:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20220721-AL-001, 20220721-AL-003, 20220722-AL-001).

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2022-07-25T14:05:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 

Prior to the onset of the current Radiation Belt Enhancement event, the energetic electron fluxes had remained slightly elevated after the previous RBE event with ID 2022-07-25T14:05:00-RBE-001. The current Radiation Belt Enhancement is likely associated with the same arrival of CMEs with IDs 2022-07-21T01:36:00-CME-001 and 2022-07-21T01:48:00-CME-001 which were responsible for the previous Radiation Belt Enhancement, but this event is still under analysis.

## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2022-07-29T13:08Z.

Estimated speed: ~769 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 20 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 109/9 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2022-07-29T13:08:00-CME-001

The flank of the CME will reach OSIRIS-REx at 2022-08-01T05:30Z (plus minus 7 hours).

## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2022-07-29T00:36Z.

Estimated speed: ~630 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 20 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 39/-21 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2022-07-29T00:36:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Mars (glancing blow), Parker Solar Probe (glancing blow), and STEREO B (glancing blow).  The flank of the CME will reach Mars at 2022-08-02T10:00Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2022-07-31T12:00Z, and STEREO B at 2022-08-01T19:00Z (plus minus 7 hours).

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for July 20, 2022 - July 26, 2022
##
## Message Issue Date: 2022-07-27T21:55:38Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2022-07-20T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2022-07-26T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20220727-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity varied between minor and moderate levels during this reporting period. There were 5 O-type and 8 C-type CMEs (see details below).
 
Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the combined leading edge of the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2022-07-21T01:36Z associated with the C5.6 class flare which peaked at 2022-07-21T01:11Z and the O-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2022-07-21T01:48Z may affect Parker Solar Probe at 2022-07-22T07:20Z, STEREO A at 2022-07-22T19:09Z, STEREO B at 2022-07-22T21:45Z, Mars at 2022-07-25T18:00Z (glancing blow), and NASA missions near Earth at about 2022-07-22T16:38Z (plus minus 7 hours) with the roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index was 8-9 (severe to extreme) (see notifications 20220721-AL-001 and 20220721-AL-003). Additionally, an ensemble simulation of these CMEs with 24 ensemble members each was made (see notification 20220722-AL-001 and full details at https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2022-07-21_ncmes2_sims24_HILOX139/Detailed_results_20220721_022000_ncmes2_sims24_HILOX139.txt). The arrival of the combination of these CMEs was detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2022-07-23T02:28Z (more details below) and STEREO A at 2022-07-23T01:52Z.

Additionally, the following non-Earth directed CMEs were predicted to impact:

CME Starting time  |  Predicted Mission Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
---------------------------------------------------------------------
2022-07-22T17:24Z   OSIRIS-REx at 2022-07-25T03:03Z and Solar Orbiter at 2022-07-25T02:51Z (see notification 20220722-AL-002)
2022-07-23T19:00Z   Solar Orbiter at 2022-07-25T11:40Z (see notification 20220725-AL-001)
2022-07-23T19:09Z   Solar Orbiter at 2022-07-25T11:40Z (see notification 20220725-AL-001)

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp = 5 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2022-07-21T15:00Z-21:00Z and 2022-07-23T03:00Z-06:00Z. The elevated value of Kp on 2022-07-21 was likely associated by the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream on 2022-07-21 (see notification 20220721-AL-002).  The elevated value of Kp on 2022-07-23 was likely associated by the combined arrival of the O-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2022-07-21T01:48Z and the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2022-07-21T01:36Z mentioned above. 

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 1000 pfu starting at 2022-07-20T01:00Z possibly due to the arrival of the C-type CME first seen in STEREO A COR2 at 2022-07-15T15:23Z (see notification 20220720-AL-001).  A separate threshold crossing occurred at 2022-07-25T14:05Z due to the arrival of the aforementioned combined CMEs on 2022-07-23 (see notifications 20220725-AL-002, 20220725-AL-003, and 20220727-AL-001). 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 


Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been minor to moderate this week due to the radiation belt enhancement described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2022-07-27T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2022-08-02T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between minor and moderate levels during the outlook period.  There are currently six numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk which have exhibited B-class and C-class flaring activity during the reporting period. An unnumbered Active Region near S17E85 has recently rotated onto the Earth-facing disk as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO and may exhibit some flaring activity during the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. As seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO, there are several coronal holes structures currently visible on the Earth-facing disk. One of these structures which recently crossed the Earth-facing central meridian and is currently centered near N15W10, may become geoeffective on or around 2022-07-29. The other structures, visible in the southeastern quadrant of the Earth-facing disk, may begin to reach geoeffective longitudes on or around 2022-08-01. The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt that began on 2022-07-25 may remain elevated during the beginning part of the outlook period (see notification 20220727-AL-001).

## Summary:

Multiple CMEs have been detected as follows:

1: S-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2022-07-26T16:23Z.

Estimated speed: ~456 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 19 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 55/3 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2022-07-26T16:23:00-CME-001


2. C-type was CME detected by SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2022-07-27T04:00Z.

Estimated speed: ~781 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 26 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 52/32 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2022-07-27T04:00:00-CME-001


Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the combined front of the CMEs may impact Mars, OSIRIS-REx (glancing blow), and Parker Solar Probe (glancing blow).  The leading edge or flank of the CMEs will reach Mars at 2022-07-31T05:09Z, OSIRIS-REx at 2022-07-29T17:00Z, and Parker Solar Probe at 2022-07-29T06:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 


Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CMEs: 2022-07-26T16:23:00-CME-001, 2022-07-27T04:00:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20220727_001300_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20220727_001300_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_Mars_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20220727_001300_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_Osiris_timeline.gif


## Notes: 

The S-type CME with Activity ID 2022-07-26T16:23:00-CME-001 may be associated with C8.5 flare with ID 2022-07-26T15:12:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2022-07-26T15:35Z. 
Parameters of the C-type CME with Activity ID 2022-07-27T04:00:00-CME-001 are approximate since its front is not seen in STEREO A COR2 imagery because of a large data gap.

## Message ID: 20220727-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux first crossed the threshold of 1000 pfu starting at 2022-07-25T14:05Z. The most recent crossing of the 1000 pfu threshold was at 2022-07-26T17:20Z and the fluxes are currently elevated but below the threshold.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by  CME with ID 2022-07-21T01:36:00-CME-001 and  CME with ID 2022-07-21T01:48:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20220725-AL-002 and 20220725-AL-003).

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2022-07-25T14:05:00-RBE-001.

Ensemble modeling update on CMEs with IDs 2022-07-21T01:36:00-CME-001 and 2022-07-21T01:48:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20220721-AL-003). Based on analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CMEs may impact STEREO A and STEREO B. For 24 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- STEREO A between about 2022-07-22T13:02Z and 2022-07-22T20:31Z (average arrival 2022-07-22T16:42Z) for 100% of simulations.
- STEREO B between about 2022-07-22T16:38Z and 2022-07-23T01:33Z (average arrival 2022-07-22T20:31Z) for 100% of simulations.

Additionally the CMEs are estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2022-07-22T11:40Z and 2022-07-22T19:30Z (average arrival 2022-07-22T15:13Z) for 100% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 100% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 8-9 range (severe to extreme).

## Notes:
While the halo associated with CME: 2022-07-21T01:48Z is fast, its coronagraph signature is quite diffuse, so the resulting Kp may be lower than indicated by the simulation outputs.

These CME events (2022-07-21T01:36:00-CME-001 and 2022-07-21T01:48:00-CME-001) are also predicted to have an impacts at Parker Solar Probe at 2022-07-22T07:20Z and Mars at 2022-07-25T18:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) based on previous heliospheric modeling (see notification 20220721-AL-003).  The previous heliospheric modeling simulated these two CMEs (2022-07-21T01:36:00-CME-001 and 2022-07-21T01:48:00-CME-001) along with one other CME (2022-07-21T01:25:00-CME-001) which is not anticipated to impact any missions.

Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate level during this reporting period with 4 M-class flares and 9 C-type CMEs(see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the C-type CME first visible in STEREO A COR2 at 2022-07-15T15:23Z may affect Parker Solar Probe at 2022-07-18T00:41Z, STEREO A at 2022-07-19T05:05Z, STEREO B at 2022-07-19T01:33Z, Mars (glancing blow) at 2022-07-20T10:30Z, and NASA missions near Earth at 2022-07-18T23:11Z (plus minus 7 hours) with the roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index 4-6 (below minor to moderate) (see notification 20220716-AL-003).  Additionally, an ensemble simulation of this CME with 48 ensemble members was made (see notification 20220716-AL-004 and full details at https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2022-07-16_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX137/Detailed_results_20220715_172400_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX137.txt).  The arrival of this CME at L1 was likely detected by DSCOVR and ACE around 2022-07-18T20:40Z (see notification 20220718-AL-003).

It was also estimated that the C-type CME first visible in STEREO A COR2 at 2022-07-16T17:09Z may affect Parker Solar Probe at 2022-07-19T03:45Z, STEREO B at 2022-07-20T06:42Z, Mars (glancing blow) at 2022-07-21T19:00Z, and NASA missions near Earth at 2022-07-20T06:48Z (plus minus 7 hours) with the roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index 3-5 (below minor to minor) (see notification 20220717-AL-001).  Additionally, an ensemble simulation of this CME with 48 ensemble members was made (see notification 20220718-AL-001 and full details at https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2022-07-17_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX138/Detailed_results_20220716_170900_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX138.txt).

Additionally, the following non-Earth directed CMEs were predicted to impact:
CME Starting time  |  Predicted Mission Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
2022-07-13T13:25Z   Mars at 2022-07-17T07:47Z, OSIRIS-REx (minor impact) at 2022-07-16T05:00Z, Parker Solar Probe (minor impact) at 2022-07-15T16:00Z (see notification 20220713-AL-001)
2022-07-17T02:38Z   OSIRIS-REx at 2022-07-19T19:34Z, Mars (glancing blow) at 2022-07-21T15:00Z, Juno (glancing blow) at 2022-08-08T07:00Z (see notifications 20220717-AL-002, 20220717-AL-003)
2022-07-18T16:36Z   Solar Orbiter at 2022-07-21T14:26Z (see notification 20220718-AL-004)

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period 2022-07-19T06:00Z-09:00Z. This elevated value of Kp was likely caused by the arrival of the C-type CME first visible in STEREO A COR2 at 2022-07-15T15:23Z.  This arrival was associated with the interplanetary shock detected by DSCOVR and ACE at 2022-07-18T20:40Z (notification 20220718-AL-003).  In addition, the interplanetary shock may have been associated with a strong compression of the magnetosphere.  Simulations carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center indicated that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma was close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2022-07-19T13:23Z (see notifications 20220719-AL-001, 20220719-AL-002).

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 1000 pfu starting at 2022-07-16T07:20Z and remained elevated until 2022-07-18.  The elevated energetic electron flux levels were likely caused by the high speed stream starting on 2022-07-12, which had a maximum speed of 589 km/s (see notifications 20220716-AL-001, 20220716-AL-002, 20220718-AL-002).  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to minor this week due to elevated energetic electron fluxes in the outer radiation belt described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2022-07-20T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2022-07-26T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between minor and moderate levels throughout the outlook period. There are currently nine numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13058 (N13W00) produced 2 M-class flares and several C-class flares during the reporting period.  Active Region 13057 (N15W37) produced one M-class flare during the reporting period.  Active Region 13056 (S16W57) is magnetically complex and has generated some C-class flaring but is expected to rotate off the Earth-facing disk by 2022-07-22. All of these regions may remain active for the next upcoming period. 
 
Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels throughout the outlook period. Two large coronal holes crossed the Earth-facing central meridian on 2022-07-18 and may become geoeffective around 2022-07-22.  We may expect some geomagnetic activity by the arrival of the C-type CME first visible in STEREO A COR2 at 2022-07-16T17:09Z mentioned above.  Additionally, there is a possible arrival of a Solar Sector Boundary Crossing around 2022-07-21 as shown in the ambient ENLIL models.  Finally, the > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt has become elevated following the arrival of the C-type CME first visible in STEREO A COR2 at 2022-07-15T15:23Z, mentioned above (see notification 20220720-AL-001).

## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux dropped below the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2022-07-18T05:50Z but remains elevated. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are likely caused by the high speed stream starting on 2022-07-12, which had a maximum speed of 589 km/s (see notifications 20220716-AL-001, 20220716-AL-002).

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2022-07-16T07:20:00-RBE-001.

## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate levels during this reporting period with 3 M-class flares, 4 O-type, and 3 C-type CMEs (see details below).  

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2022-07-08T20:48Z may affect STEREO A at 2022-07-11T04:12Z, STEREO B at 2022-07-11T19:55Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2022-07-10T23:00Z, and impact NASA missions near Earth at about 2022-07-11T07:56Z (plus minus 7 hours) with the roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index 6-8 (moderate to severe) (see notification 20220709-AL-002). Additionally, an ensemble simulation of this CME with 48 ensemble members was made (see notification 20220709-AL-004 and full details at https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2022-07-09_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX136/Detailed_results_20220708_233100_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX136.txt).  The arrival of this CME at L1 was likely detected by DSCOVR and ACE around 2022-07-11T09:22Z (see notification 20220711-AL-001) and at STEREO A around 2022-07-10T16:30Z.

It was also estimated that the O-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2022-07-09T23:12Z may affect Parker Solar Probe at 2022-07-11T10:18Z, STEREO B at 2022-07-12T10:12Z, and Mars at 2022-07-13T17:00Z. Additionally, this CME might give a glancing blow to NASA missions near Earth at about 2022-07-12T18:00Z (plus minus 7 hours), with the roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index 3-4 (below minor) (see notification 20220711-AL-002).

Additionally, the following non-Earth directed CMEs were predicted to impact: 
CME Starting time | Predicted Mission Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
2022-07-09T14:00Z | Mars at 2022-07-12T22:24Z, OSIRIS-REx at 2022-07-11T13:42Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2022-07-11T19:00Z (notification 20220709-AL-003)
2022-07-11T13:09Z | OSIRIS-REx at 2022-07-14T02:42Z and Solar Orbiter at 2022-07-14T08:25Z (notification 20220711-AL-003)

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 5 for the reporting period. Two separate increases of Kp to 5 were observed during the reporting period.  The first increase of Kp to 5, encompassing synoptic periods 2022-07-07T12:00Z-15:00Z and 2022-07-07T21:00Z to 2022-07-08T06:00Z, was possibly caused by the arrival at L1 of the S-type CME first visible in STEREO A COR2 at 2022-07-03T03:09Z, which was associated with the interplanetary shock detected by DSCOVR and ACE around 2022-07-07T08:08Z and a modeled compression of the Earth's magnetosphere starting around 2022-07-07T13:15Z (see notifications 20220707-AL-001, 20220707-AL-004, 20220707-AL-002, and 20220707-AL-003). The other increase of Kp to 5 occurred during the 2022-07-12T12:00Z-15:00Z synoptic period and was likely caused by the combined arrival of the C-type CME first visible in STEREO A COR2 at 2022-07-08T20:48Z detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE around 2022-07-11T09:22Z (see notifications 20220711-AL-001, 20220709-AL-002, 20220709-AL-004) and a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2022-07-12. 

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

A solar energetic particle event was detected by SOHO during the reporting period. The flux of both the 15.8-39.8 MeV and the 28.2-50.1 MeV protons channels at SOHO exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2022-07-09T15:23Z (see notification 20220709-AL-001). This solar energetic particle event was associated with the C8.5 flare from Active Region 13047 that peaked at 2022-07-09T13:48Z and the associated C-type CME first detected by SOHO LASCO C2 at 2022-07-09T14:00Z. These events also caused minor elevations of the energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A above background levels, but the fluxes at GOES and STEREO A remained below their respective thresholds of 1 pfu and 10^(-1) pfu/MeV.

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate this week due to the solar energetic particle event described above.

Solar activity is expected to vary between minor and moderate levels throughout the outlook period. There are currently five numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13056 (S16E26) produced 2 M-class flares and many C-class flares during the reporting period. Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

## Summary:

Solar activity was at minor to moderate levels during this reporting period.  There were 1 O-type CMEs and 7 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the following non-Earth directed CMEs were predicted to impact: 

CME Starting time  Predicted Mission Impacts
2022-06-28T19:00Z   Mars at 2022-07-02T14:51Z and OSIRIS-REx at 2022-07-01T14:51Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notification 20220629-AL-001)
2022-06-28T23:12Z   Mars at 2022-07-02T14:51Z and OSIRIS-REx at 2022-07-01T14:51Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notification 20220629-AL-001)
2022-06-29T23:12Z   OSIRIS-REx at 2022-07-02T08:59Z and Mars at 2022-07-03T11:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notification 20220630-AL-001)
2022-06-30T03:24Z   Solar Orbiter at 2022-07-02T16:01Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notification 20220630-AL-002)
2022-07-03T04:12Z   OSIRIS-REx at 2022-07-05T11:59Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notification 20220703-AL-002)

Additionally, it was estimated that the C-type CME first visible in STEREO A COR2 at 2022-07-05T04:24Z may impact Parker Solar Probe at 2022-07-07T06:41Z, STEREO B at 2022-07-08T12:43Z, and NASA missions near Earth at about 2022-07-08T14:30Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 3-5 (below minor to minor) (see notification 20220705-AL-001).  An ensemble simulation of this CME with 24 ensemble members estimated that the leading edge of the CME may impact STEREO B between about 2022-07-08T11:15Z and 2022-07-08T19:47Z (average arrival 2022-07-08T14:26Z) for 79% of simulations and NASA missions near Earth between about 2022-07-08T12:28Z and 2022-07-08T18:25Z (average arrival 2022-07-08T14:19Z) for 33% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 75% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-4 range (below minor) (see notification 20220706-AL-001).

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 5 for the reporting period. The highest values of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic periods 2022-07-02T03:00Z-06:00Z and 2022-07-04T03:00Z-06:00Z.  The first synoptic period of Kp=5 was likely caused by the arrival of the CME first visible in STEREO A COR2 at 2022-06-26T18:23Z, associated with the interplanetary shock detected by DSCOVR and ACE at 2022-07-01T09:05Z (see notification 20220702-AL-001).  The second synoptic period of Kp=5 was likely caused by the arrival of the CME first visible in STEREO A COR2 at 2022-06-29T02:09Z, associated with the interplanetary shock detected by DSCOVR and ACE at 2022-07-03T07:01Z (see notification 20220703-AL-001).

The >2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected at GOES remained elevated above 1000 pfu at the beginning of the reporting period. These elevated energetic electron flux levels were likely caused by the coronal hole high speed stream which arrived on 2022-06-25, reaching a maximum speed of approximately 750 km/s (see notification 20220630-AL-003).  Energetic electron fluxes returned to background levels late on 2022-07-01 and remained below the threshold for the rest of the reporting period.  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period.

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to minor due the elevated energetic electron fluxes mentioned above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2022-07-06T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2022-07-12T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between minor and moderate levels during the outlook period. There are currently several numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk, including newly-numbered Active Region 13054 (N21W21).  Active Region 13053 (N14E72) has been the most active and magnetically complex of these regions since it was numbered on 2022-07-05, and is likely to remain active during the outlook period.  Additionally, an unnumbered Active Region observed over the eastern limb in STEREO A EUVI 195 imagery (near latitude N25) may rotate onto the Earth-facing disk during the first part of the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between below minor and minor levels during the outlook period.  We may expect some geomagnetic activity by the arrival of the C-type CME first visible in STEREO A COR2 at 2022-07-05T04:24Z mentioned above at missions near Earth around 2022-07-08.  Additionally, there is a possible arrival of a Solar Sector Boundary Crossing around 2022-07-08 as shown in the ambient ENLIL models.

Ensemble modeling update on CME with ID 2022-07-05T04:24:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20220705-AL-001). Based on analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO B. For 24 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- STEREO B between about 2022-07-08T11:15Z and 2022-07-08T19:47Z (average arrival 2022-07-08T14:26Z) for 79% of simulations.

Additionally the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2022-07-08T12:28Z and 2022-07-08T18:25Z (average arrival 2022-07-08T14:19Z) for 33% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 75% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-4 range (below minor).

## Notes:
This CME event (2022-07-05T04:24:00-CME-001) is also predicted to impact Parker Solar Probe at 2022-07-07T06:41Z (plus minus 7 hours) based on previous heliospheric modeling (see notification 20220705-AL-001).

Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.
